prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB (Blue) x B_ (Blue) -> 4/4 B_ (Blue)
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Green), 1/4 GG (Green)
Blue x Turquoise -> 1/2 Blue 1/2 Turquoise

data.expected: GT (Green) x GT (Green) -> 1/4 GG (Green), 1/2 GT (Green), 1/4 TT (Turquoise)

data.sampled:
: This distribution is possible. The Genotypes of the parents and offspring are:
Parent 1: BB (homozygous dominant blue)
Parent 2: B_ (homozygous recessive blue)
Offspring: BB_ (heterozygous blue) x B_ (homozygous recessive blue)
                -> 1/2 B_ (blue) + 1/4 B (blue) + 2/4 G (green),
                                     impossible
All the possible outcomes are represented in the F1 generation, where the offspring have a 25% chance of expressing each of the three possible alleles for green.<|im_end|>

data.sampled:
:
It is not possible to determine the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 generation. This is because the dominance relationship of B over G and T implies that B_ is actually dominant over T in the F1 generation, which means that G is also recessive and cannot be inherited in combination with B in the F1 generation. Therefore, the only possible combination for the F1 generation is B_ T, leading to a 1/2 ratio of BB and BTG, but no BB and GTG. The impossible distribution of phenotypes in the F1 generation is 1/4 BB, 1/2 BTG, and 1/4 GTG.<|im_end|>

Genotypes of offspring: 4/4 B_ (Blue), 1/4 G_ (Green)

1/4 G_ (Green) x BB (Blue) = 1/4 G_ (Green) (assuming there is no effect of the green allele on the blue gene)
1/4 B_ (Blue) x B_ (Blue) = 3/4 B_ (Blue)
Distribution: 4/4 B_ (Blue), 1/4 G_ (Green)

data.sampled: : This distribution is impossible. In a monohybrid inheritance, the possible offspring genotypes are BB, BG, GB, and GG. However, in this scenario, the possibility of any offspring with blue color inheritance is limited to only BB and BG, as blue alleles cannot be combined with green alleles. As there are 9 possible genotypes for a monohybrid inheritance, the total number of possible phenotype outcomes for the F1 generation is 4. Since there is a dominant blue allele, the possible outcomes from the BB and BG crosses are BB, B_ (blue), B_B_ (blue), B_B (blue), BB_, BB (blue), and BB_ (blue).<|im_end|>
